intro: Oxytropis kordkoyensis, commonly known as Kordkoy locoweed, is a flowering plant native to Central Asia, particularly found in regions of Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan. It is a member of the Fabaceae family, which includes legumes, and is characterized by its erect growth habit and compound leaves. The plant produces small, pea-like flowers that are typically pink to purple in color, blooming in the summer months. Oxytropis kordkoyensis is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in sandy or rocky soils. It is also known for its toxic properties, containing alkaloids that can be harmful to livestock.
